learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate professional skills in the workplace including effective oral and written communication, team interaction skills, time management skills, ability to work independently and uphold ethical practice.
Link theory and practice by demonstrating practical processing, research, laboratory, or problem-solving skills in a professional work environment.
Evaluate management, production, and laboratory systems in a professional work environment.
Critically reflect on events and activities during the placement using the SEAL template.

assessments.task_description:
At the conclusion of the full-day compulsory workshop, which prepares students for their 13-week industry placement with food industry hosts across South-East Queensland, students attempt a timed online quiz.

The quiz will be based on the workshop content including essential information, resources and expectations to ensure a successful and professional placement experience. It is anticipated that this assessment will facilitate students' understanding of workplace culture, professional communication and employer expectations in the Australian food industry. Additionally, students will develop awareness of workplace health and safety requirements. They will also have learnt strategies for adapting to new work environments and building professional relationships.


Duration: 20 minutes

Marks: 20 marks

Attempts: One attempt only

Question types: Multiple choice, true/false, short answer scenario-based questions.


Further details are available on the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.


This test will be taken on a UQ campus location with secure internet service. Please bring your own device for this Quiz and ensure that it is fully charged. Loan laptops may be available from the UQ Library.

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the online test/quiz: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Seek assistance from the Course Coordinator during this in-class assessment first. Contact AskUs support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you. 


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The online assessment is completed in the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site under the appropriate assessment title.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Learning Contract & Risk Assessment Document:

Students must negotiate the Learning Contract and Risk Assessment with their Placement Supervisor during the first week of placement.

When addressing the Learning Contract, discussion must include confidentiality requirements.

The completion of the Risk Assessment is done to identify hazards associated with placement activities. This is a critical task, as the document serves as evidence for any workplace insurance claims.


This assessment must be completed in person.


The relevant template is available in the Assessment Folder on the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 


The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via the submission link in the Assessment Folder on the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Using the SEAL template provided, students will reflect on events and activities during their placement that align to the following topics:

Reflective Practice 1: Challenges in the Workplace.

Reflective Practice 2: Communication.

Reflective Practice 3: Select 1 topic ONLY to reflect on from: Work Tasks OR Teamwork.

Reflective Practice 4: Select 1 topic ONLY to reflect on from: Working with New Technologies & AI in the Food Industry OR Adaptability & Flexibility.

Reflective Practice 5: Food Industry insights.

Reflective Practice 6: Lifelong learning.


Each reflection will consist of two components:

  • Written: Describe the situation, its impact and the actions taken.
  • Recorded: Summarise key learnings in a 2-minute video.


Reflections must be submitted using the appropriate links in the Assessment Folder on the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site. Submissions are due by 17:00 Thursday in Weeks 3, 5, 7, 9 and 11, and by 17:00 Friday in Week 14 (after the Employability Workshop). These due dates apply throughout the placement schedule, including the mid-semester break. Each reflection is worth 7% of your overall grade.


Further details are available on the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via the respective links in the Assessment Folder in the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.

assessments.assessment_title: Sequential Self-Evaluation & Feedback Action Plan for Supervisor Report 1
assessments.weighting: <dd>7% Self-Evaluation contributes 3% and Feedback Action Plan contributes 4% to the overall weighting of 7% </dd>
assessments.task_description:
Self-Evaluation Purpose:

The purpose of this self‑evaluation is to encourage students to critically reflect on their early performance, professional conduct and progress in the first three weeks of their industry placement. By assessing their strengths, areas for development and alignment with workplace expectations, students build self‑awareness and take an active role in their professional growth. This reflection also supports the interpretation of Supervisor Report 1, enabling students to better understand supervisor feedback and prepare for productive discussions that strengthen their workplace skills and contribute to a successful placement experience.


Student Responsibilities:

By Monday of the week the Supervisor Report 1 is due, the student must:

  • Export and compile logbook and attendance
  • Combine relevant weekly timesheets from the Excel Logbook into a single PDF.
  • Submit the following via the appropriate links in InPlace:
  • Compiled logbook and attendance pdf showing workplace attendance and a summary of weekly activities.
  • Completed self-evaluation covering the first three weeks of placement.

Weighting: 3% of final grade


Feeddback Action Plan Purpose:

As part of your professional development you will analyse the feedback provided in your Supervisor Report 1 and develop a Feedback Action Plan and submit it via InPlace. This plan will help you to reflect on your strengths, identify areas for improvement, and outline concrete steps to enhance your employability and professional skills.

By completing this task, you will:

  • Critically analyse feedback from your industry host supervisor.
  • Identify key strengths and areas for growth.
  • Develop a structured plan for improving technical, professional, and communication skills.
  • Align your personal development with industry expectations and career goals.

Weighting: 4% of final grade


Further information can be found in the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Student to submit pdf of relevant timesheets and self-reflection via InPlace.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Purpose:

The Placement Supervisor will assess the student’s progress, performance and conduct approximately three weeks after placement begins. This feedback helps identify development opportunities for the remainder of the placement.


Industry Placement Supervisor Responsibilities:

The assessment request is automatically sent to the industry placement supervisor, granting access to complete the Supervisor Report 1 in InPlace. The placement supervisor is encouraged to use the report as an opportunity to conduct a formal performance review session with the student and provide face-to-face feedback before submitting the report electronically. Further information can be found in the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.

The Supervisor Report must be submitted by the due date by the industry placement supervisor or their authorised representative.

Students who achieve 'Unsatisfactory' in any of the five evaluated areas, OR receives an overall mark of 50% or less, will have their placement paused. They will be referred to the Course Coordinator and required to attend a feedback and academic progression outcomes meeting. The student will need to implement a one-week performance plan. The Placement Supervisor will be asked to report again at the week's end, and if performance is still unsatisfactory, the student's placement will be terminated and they will have to withdraw from the course.


Further information can be found in the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Placement Supervisor to complete report in InPlace.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: As these assessments are completed by the industry host supervisor and not generated by the student, students are not responsible for late submissions for the Sequence Supervisor Reports.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Purpose:

The purpose of this progress reflection is to support students in critically evaluating their development, performance and professional growth over the duration of their industry placement. By reviewing their achievements, challenges and their progress since receiving feedback provided in Supervisor Report 1, students consolidate their learning and assess how effectively they have met workplace expectations.


Student Responsibilities:

By Monday of the week the Supervisor Report 2 is due, the student must:

  • Export and compile logbook and attendance
  • Combine relevant weekly timesheets from the Excel Logbook into a single PDF.


  • Submit the following via the appropriate links in InPlace:
  • Compiled logbook and attendance pdf showing workplace attendance and a summary of weekly activities.
  • Completed progress reflection form.


Further information can be found in the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.

assessments.task_description:
As part of the compulsory employability workshop, each student will deliver a 60-90 seconds elevator pitch to the class that effectively communicates their professional identity, industry placement experience, and career aspirations. This exercise will help students refine their ability to present themselves confidently and concisely to potential employers, industry professionals and networking contacts.

By completing this task, students will:

  • Develop a clear and compelling professional introduction.
  • Effectively highlight key skills, industry experience, and career goals.
  • Practice confident and engaging verbal communication.
  • Participate in productive peer feedback to refine their pitch for real-world networking situations, as part of our FOOD7021 community of learning.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will deliver their Elevator Pitch during the timetabled Employability Workshop held on the Friday in Teaching week 13.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.due_date:
8/06/2026 - 12/06/2026

The mock interview will take place in Exam Week 1, with the exact date and times TBC via an announcement on the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ Ultra site.
assessments.task_description:
As part of a "Mock Interview", the course coordinator will ask specific questions related to any of the six reflection topics submitted by the student during the semester. Overall, the interview will last 4-5 minutes. Students will be made aware of the timer, which will sound at 4:30 minutes, allowing them to conclude their answers. One follow-up question will be asked - answers provided could only improve the grade.

The mock interview will be recorded to ensure accuracy in grading and for review purposes.

Further information can be found in the FOOD7021 Learn.UQ blackboard site.

learning_activities.topic:
Professional Experience

Students undertake 400-480 hours of workplace experience in a host organisation under the supervision of the Placement Supervisor.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Professional Experience Students undertake 400-480 hours of workplace experience in a host organisation under the supervision of the Placement Supervisor.

learning_activities.topic:
Orientation Workshop

This activity will take place in-person on the first day of semester. Attendance is compulsory. The orientation session will be specific to FOOD7021, covering professionalism, the course requirements and discussing assessment expectations and submission requirements.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Orientation Workshop This activity will take place in-person on the first day of semester. Attendance is compulsory. The orientation session will be specific to FOOD7021, covering professionalism, the course requirements and discussing assessment expectations and submission requirements.

learning_activities.topic:
Employability Workshop

The post-placement Employability Workshop is held during Teaching Week 13 of semester. Attendance is compulsory. This will be an in-person activity, where students will have the opportunity to unpack their recent work integrated learning experience, as well as have the opportunity to network and hear from previous FOOD7021 graduates currently working in the Food Manufacturing Industry in South-East Queensland.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04
